grpc-testing really wants to test this :)

Past that, thanks everyone for taking a look at this. I have a few questions on this PR:

1) Should I setup the directory structure like this? Since a lot of the code can be shared with the php directory (like all the tests) it may be better to place this under the PHP folder in some way. I also haven't added any different tests here since all the same ones from the php library can be used.

2) I have been working through a few remaining segfaults and memory issues and have gotten stuck. For instance the following stack trace (https://gist.github.com/RyanGordon/d812dbe22d599ce5d54365c5f64b205c) has plagued me and may be related to calling `vm_call_user_func` (https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/11553/files#diff-b162b6e5f93a243a83db41b6aa4fa912R124) in some form and memory not being set properly. There's also a separate segfault that happens and I haven't been able to locate why yet: https://gist.github.com/RyanGordon/31246ced243d72bf2fbd1fa48f4cb3b5

Any theories or help on the segfault/error would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
I was able to fix the segfault and memory corruption issues mentioned above; I'm still working through a few more issues but those should hopefully not take too long

A quick update: I've fixed any obvious issues and now have connection, querying and related things working with this. Next, I'm going to be going through and evaluating for thread safety and testing it, then I'll ensure all unit tests pass and lastly I'll do a round of memory leak testing.

I'm still curious for feedback on how this should be structured? Should I merge it in with the PHP directory in some form or copy tests over, etc?
@RyanGordon Thanks for the contribution! This is amazing. Great work! We are still taking a look at this and are discussing folder structure. We will have an update soon. Thanks!

So there's good news and bad news.

:thumbsup: The good news is that everyone that needs to sign a CLA (the pull request submitter and all commit authors) have done so.  Everything is all good there.

:confused: The bad news is that it appears that one or more commits were authored by someone other than the pull request submitter.  We need to confirm that they're okay with their commits being contributed to this project.  Please have them confirm that here in the pull request.

*Note to project maintainer: This is a terminal state, meaning the `cla/google` commit status will not change from this state. It's up to you to confirm consent of the commit author(s) and merge this pull request when appropriate.*

<!-- need_author_consent -->

Just wanted to give an update on this: The extension is now stable other than one or more memory leaks I am tracking down. I also have a few changes to make to get all of the unit tests to pass but they're mostly around the type of exception that the unit test expects from the extension.

> Please have them confirm that here in the pull request.

i'm ok with that.

Hi @RyanGordon, thanks again for your contribution! I have a couple of questions

1. I noticed that you removed the `lib/Grpc` code (which was in Hack?). Does that mean the HHVM extension will work with the PHP `lib/Grpc` code? And I suppose same for all the unit tests as well? So this PR really only needs the HHVM C extension?

2. What's the use of the `composer.json` in this context? That is only used to pull in other packages dependency to run the PHP lib code right? Coz there's no PHP code, per se, to submit this as a composer package right?

3. We are still deciding on the folder structure. But now that it appears that this PR will only have the HHVM C extension as "new code". I am leaning towards putting this in the `grpc/src/php/ext` subtree. What do you think?

Hi @stanley-cheung 

1. Yes, it turns out the code in `lib/Grpc` doesn't need any changes for it to run in hack and the header isn't necessary unless we're adding typing information. I removed the folder for those reasons. I do have a separate file to run HHVM unit tests locally, since I am not sure how to setup the hhvm framework for the CI. It also appears the `autoload.php` that the php unit tests reference isn't in this repo, so I just used my own autoloader instead to run tests.

2. It does look like `composer.json` is indeed not needed in this PR (No differences from the PHP composer package); I will remove it.

3. That sounds correct to me. Should we put it under `grpc/src/php/ext/hhvm`?

Hello @stanley-cheung,

I've been able to get the extension reliably working up to a few threads, and then I hit a race condition:

```
(gdb) bt
#0  0x000000000130891e in void HPHP::MemoryManager::refreshStatsImpl<true>(HPHP::MemoryUsageStats&) ()
#1  0x00000000033400c0 in HPHP::MemoryManager::newSlab(unsigned int) ()
#2  0x000000000333fbda in HPHP::MemoryManager::mallocSmallSizeSlow(unsigned int, unsigned int) ()
#3  0x0000000000d5b810 in HPHP::SystemLib::AllocStdClassObject() ()
#4  0x00007fc9ca9d96fb in HPHP::plugin_get_metadata (ptr=0x7fc9978a96f0, context=..., cb=0x7fc9ca608670, user_data=0x7fc98466ba00) at hhvm/grpc/src/hhvm/ext/grpc/call_credentials.cpp:122
#5  0x00007fc9ca609cd9 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#6  0x00007fc9ca60c183 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#7  0x00007fc9ca609659 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#8  0x00007fc9ca614e77 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#9  0x00007fc9ca615698 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#10 0x00007fc9ca615e26 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#11 0x00007fc9ca5bbf46 in grpc_combiner_continue_exec_ctx () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#12 0x00007fc9ca5c97a8 in grpc_exec_ctx_flush () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#13 0x00007fc9ca5c9b1a in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#14 0x00007fc9ca6304b7 in ?? () from /usr/local/lib/libgrpc.so.4
#15 0x00007fc9d98e3dc5 in start_thread (arg=0x7fc982ffe700) at pthread_create.c:308
#16 0x00007fc9d417973d in clone () at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/x86_64/clone.S:113
```

I've dug in a bunch and it appears that essentially HHVM is not thread safe within a request. Here gRPC is calling `plugin_get_metadata` (https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/11553/files#diff-b162b6e5f93a243a83db41b6aa4fa912R119) from a different thread, which is in turn calling HHVM application code which is not thread-safe within the context of a single request and so a segfault happens in a race. It appears as if this behavior will [not be supported](https://github.com/facebook/hhvm/issues/2827#issuecomment-172046327) by HHVM.

My question is, is there a way to workaround this behavior in gRPC? Ideally, I would like any gRPC calls to come back to the same thread that the HHVM request is running on, rather than executing any HHVM application code under a different thread. Is this possible?
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
Hi @RyanGordon What you mentioned seems like the same issue as https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7608.

Ah yes, that does look very similar and your analysis agrees with mine per https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7608#issuecomment-239326444

I don't suppose this mechanism has been implemented yet?
